&nbsp; &nbsp; Rate = k, 2 N<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> (g) ➞ 4 NO<sub>2</sub> (g) + O<sub>2</sub> (g);&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Rate = k[N<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>], 2 NO<sub>2</sub> (g) + F<sub>2</sub> (g) ➞ 2 NO<sub>2</sub>F (g);&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Rate = k[NO<sub>2</sub>][F<sub>2</sub>], 2 NO (g) + O<sub>2</sub> (g) ➞ 2 NO<sub>2</sub> (g);&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Rate = k[NO]<sup>2</sup>[O<sub>2</sub>]}","choices":["${zeroth, first, second, third}","${first, second, third, zeroth}","${second, third, zeroth, first}","${third, zeroth, first, second}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"based on the rate law (${Rate = k, Rate = k[N<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>], Rate = k[NO<sub>2</sub>][F<sub>2</sub>], Rate = k[NO]<sup>2</sup>[O<sub>2</sub>]}), the order of the reaction is ${zeroth, first, second, third}, because if you add the exponents (orders) of each reactant, then you will get ${0, 1, 2, 3}"},{"group":"","stem":"What is are the units for the k in the following rate law.<br>Rate = k${ , [A], [A]<sup>2</sup>, [A][B], [A][B]<sup>2</sup>, [A]<sup>2</sup>[B], [A][B][C]}","choices":["${M/s or Ms<sup>-1</sup>, 1/s or s<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(Ms) or M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(Ms) or M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(M<sup>2</sup>S) or M<sup>-2</sup>S<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(M<sup>2</sup>S) or M<sup>-2</sup>S<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(M<sup>2</sup>S) or M<sup>-2</sup>S<sup>-1</sup>}","${1/s or s<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(Ms) or M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(M<sup>2</sup>S) or M<sup>-2</sup>S<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(M<sup>2</sup>S) or M<sup>-2</sup>S<sup>-1</sup>, M/s or Ms<sup>-1</sup>, M/s or Ms<sup>-1</sup>, M/s or Ms<sup>-1</sup>}","${1/(Ms) or M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(M<sup>2</sup>S) or M<sup>-2</sup>S<sup>-1</sup>, M/s or Ms<sup>-1</sup>, M/s or Ms<sup>-1</sup>,&nbsp;1/s or s<sup>-1</sup>,1/s or s<sup>-1</sup>,1/s or s<sup>-1</sup>}","1/(M<sup>3</sup>s) or M<sup>-3</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"Based on the rate law (Rate = k${ , [A], [A]<sup>2</sup>, [A][B], [A][B]<sup>2</sup>, [A]<sup>2</sup>[B], [A][B][C]}), the overall order of the reaction is ${zeroth, first, second, second, third, third, third}, so the exponents for units of the rate constant will add to ${0, -1, -2, -2, -3, -3, -3}.&nbsp; Since seconds is always to the -1 power, molarity will have to be to the ${+1, 0, -1, -1, -2, -2, -2} power.&nbsp; Thus ${M/s or Ms<sup>-1</sup>, 1/s or s<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(Ms) or M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(Ms) or M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(M<sup>2</sup>S) or M<sup>-2</sup>S<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(M<sup>2</sup>S) or M<sup>-2</sup>S<sup>-1</sup>, 1/(M<sup>2</sup>S) or M<sup>-2</sup>S<sup>-1</sup>} is the answer."},{"group":"","stem":"The reaction A + B ➞ C + D, has a rate constant of ${a 1 9 3} × 10<sup>-${e 3 5 1}</sup> ${M<sup>-2</sup> ,M<sup>-1</sup> , ,M }s<sup>-1</sup> at 0°C, what is the overall order of the reaction?","choices":["${3, 2, 1, 0}","${0, 3, 2, 1}","${1, 0, 3, 2}","${2, 1, 0, 3}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"If you add the exponents of the rate constant units (${M<sup>-2</sup> ,M<sup>-1</sup> , ,M }s<sup>-1</sup>), you get ${-3, -2, -1, 0}, so the order of the overall reaction is ${3, 2, 1, 0}."},{"group":"rate law from initial rate","stem":"Given the initial rate data below, what is the rate law for the following reaction?<br>A (g) + B&nbsp;(g) <span style=\"font-size: 10.5pt;\">➞</span> C&nbsp;(g)<br><br>\r\n<table style=\"border-collapse: collapse; 3]/=[${r}/100000000; 3]<br><span class=\"math-tex\">\\( (\\frac{[2.0]}{[1.0]} )^y \\)</span>= ${1, 8, 4}<br>y = ${0, 3, 2}<br><br>Thus the rate law will be:<br>Rate = K[A]<sup>${0, 3, 2}</sup>[B]<sup>${0, 3, 2}</sup> = K${[B]<sup>2</sup>, [A]<sup>3</sup>, [A]<sup>2</sup>[B]<sup>3</sup>}</p>"},{"group":"half life","stem":"The following reaction is a second order reaction.&nbsp; If the rate constant is ${k 0.4 0.9 3} M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>, and the original concentration of O<sub>3</sub> is ${c 0.8 2 3}x10<sup>-2 </sup>M, then what is the half-life?<br><br>\r\n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">2 O<sub>3</sub> (g) ➞ 2 O<sub>2</sub> (g)</div>","choices":["=[1/(${c}*10^-2*${k})] s","=[0.693147181/${k}] s","=[(${c}*10^-2)/(2*${k})] s","=[${k}/(${c}*10^-2)] s"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"Since this is a second order reaction, the half-life equation is <span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{1}{K[A]_0} = t_{1/2} \\)</span><br>Substituting in ${k} M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup> for K, and ${c}x10<sup>-2 </sup>M for [A]<sub>0</sub> gives:<br>t<sub>1/2</sub> = 1/(${k} M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup> x ${c}x10<sup>-2 </sup>M) = =[1/(${c}*10^-2*${k})] s"},{"group":"half life","stem":"The following reaction is a first order reaction.&nbsp; If the rate constant is ${k 1 3 3}x10<sup>-4</sup> s<sup>-1</sup>, and the original concentration of &nbsp;N<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>&nbsp;is ${c 2 4 3}x10<sup>-2 </sup>M, then what is the half-life?<br><br>\r\n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">2 N<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> (g) ➞ 4 NO<sub>2</sub> (g) + O<sub>2</sub> (g)</div>","choices":["=[1/(${c}*10^-2*${k}*10^-4)] s","=[0.693147181/(${k}*10^-4)] s","=[(${c}*10^-2)/(2*${k}*10^-4)] s","=[(${k}*10^-4)/(${c}*10^-2)] s"],"correct":["1"],"solution":"Since this is a second order reaction, the half-life equation is <span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{0.693}{K} = t_{1/2} \\)</span><br>Substituting in ${k} s<sup>-1</sup> for K, gives:<br>t<sub>1/2</sub> = 0.693/(${k} s<sup>-1</sup>) = =[1/(${c}*10^-2*${k}*10^-4)] s"},{"group":"half life","stem":"The following reaction is a zero order reaction.&nbsp; If the rate constant is ${k 1 3 3} M/s, and the original concentration of&nbsp; A&nbsp;is ${c 2 4 3}x10<sup>-2 </sup>M, then what is the half-life?<br><br>\r\n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">A (g) + 2 B (g)<span style=\"font-size: 10.5pt;\">➞</span><span style=\"font-size: 10.5pt;\">&nbsp;AB</span><sub>2</sub><span style=\"font-size: 10.5pt;\"> (g)</span></div>","choices":["=[1/(${c}*10^-2*${k})] s","=[0.693147181/(${k})] s","=[(${c}*10^-2)/(2*${k})] s","=[(${k})/(${c}*10^-2)] s"],"correct":["2"],"solution":"Since this is a second order reaction, the half-life equation is <span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{[A]_0}{2K} = t_{1/2} \\)</span><br>Substituting in ${k} Ms<sup>-1</sup> for K, and ${c}x10<sup>-2 </sup>M for [A]<sub>0</sub> gives:<br>t<sub>1/2</sub> = (${c}x10<sup>-2 </sup>M)/(2x${k} Ms<sup>-1</sup>) = =[(${c}*10^-2)/(2*${k})] s"},{"group":"integrated rate law","stem":"The decomposition of cyclopropane to propene is a first-order reaction that has a rate constant of ${k 5 8 3}x10<sup>-4</sup> s<sup>-1</sup>. If the initial concentration of cyclopropane is ${c 1 9 3} M, what is the concentration of cyclopropane after ${t 2 800 3} s?","choices":["=[-1*${k}*10^-4*${t}+${c}] M","=[${c}*e^(-${k}*10^-4*${t})] M","=[(-1*${k}*10^-4*${t}+1/${c})^-1] M","=[${k}*10^-4*${t}*${c}] M"],"correct":["1"],"solution":"The integrate rate law for a first order reaction is <span class=\"math-tex\">\\( ln\\frac{[A]_t}{[A]_0} = -kt \\)</span><br>Taking the inverse log of both sides gives:<br><span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{[A]_t}{[A]_0} = e^{-kt} \\)</span>, multiplying both sides by [A]<sub>0</sub> gives:<br><span class=\"math-tex\">\\( [A]_t = [A]_0 x e^{-kt} \\)</span><br>Plugging in ${c} M for [A]<sub>0</sub>, ${k}x10<sup>-4</sup> s<sup>-1</sup> for K, and ${t} s for t gives:<br>[A]<sub>t</sub> = ${c} M&nbsp;x e<sup>(-${k}x10-4 s-1 x ${t} s)</sup><br>[A]<sub>t</sub> = =[${c}*e^(-${k}*10^-4*${t})] M"},{"group":"integrated rate law","stem":"The reaction of nitrogen monoxide with oxygen is second-order with respect to nitrogen monoxide, and has a rate constant of ${k 0.2 0.3 3} <span style=\"font-size: 11.6667px;\">M<sup>-1</sup></span>s<sup>-1</sup>. of the reaction to decrease."],"correct":["0"],"solution":"If you think about a generic rate equation such as Rate = k[A][B], anything that affects the rate, that isn't a change in concentration of A pressure is ${p 30 60 3} mm Hg at ${t 30 60 3}°C and has a ΔH<sub>vap</sub> of ${h 20 40 3} kJ/mol.","choices":["=[(((log(760/${p})/log(2.71828))/((-${h}*1000)/8.3145))+1/(${t}+273.15))^-1] K","=[(((log(760/${p})/log(2.71828))/((-${h}*1000)/8.3145))+1/(${t}))^-1] K","=[(((log(760/${p})/log(2.71828))/((-${h}*1000)/0.08206) )+1/(${t}+273.15) )^-1] K","=[(((log(${p}/760)/log(2.71828))/((-${h}*1000)/8.3145) )+1/(${t}+273.15))^-1] K"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>To determine the normal boiling point of a substance, we need to find the temperature at which its vapor pressure is equal to the atmospheric pressure at 760 mm Hg.</p>\r\n<p>Given: <br>T<sub>1</sub>: ${t}°C<br>T<sub>2</sub>: ?<br>P<sub>1</sub>: ${p} mm Hg<br>P<sub>2</sub> = 760 mm Hg (normal pressure)&nbsp;<br>ΔH<sub>vap</sub> = ${h} kJ/mol<br>R = gas constant (8.3145 J/mol·K)</p>\r\n<p>To calculate the normal boiling point, we can use the Clausius-Clapeyron equation:</p>\r\n<p>ln(P<sub>2</sub>/P<sub>1</sub>) = -(ΔH<sub>vap</sub>/R) * (1/T<sub>2</sub> - 1/T<sub>1</sub>)</p>\r\n<p>Converting the given values to K and J:<br>T<sub>1</sub>: ${t}°C + 273.15 = =[${t}+273.15] K<br>ΔH<sub>vap</sub> = ${h} kJ/mol = ${h} × 1000J/1 kJ = =[${h}*1000] J/mol</p>\r\n<p>ln(P2/P1) = -(ΔH<sub>vap</sub>/R) * (1/T<sub>2</sub> - 1/T<sub>1</sub>) <br>ln(760 mm Hg/ ${p} mm Hg) = -(=[${h}*1000] J/mol / 8.3145 J/mol·K) * (1/T<sub>2</sub> - 1/=[${t}+273.15] K)</p>\r\n<p>Simplifying: ln(=[760/${p}]) = -=[${h}*1000/ 8.3145] K * (1/T<sub>2</sub> - 1/=[${t}+273.15] K)</p>\r\n<p>Now, let's solve for T2:<br>&nbsp;=[ln(760/${p})/(-${h}*1000/8.3145)] K = (1/T<sub>2</sub> - 1/=[${t}+273.15] K)<br>&nbsp;=[ln(760/${p})/(-${h}*1000/8.3145)] 1/K = 1/T<sub>2</sub> - 1/=[${t}+273.15] K<br>&nbsp;=[ln(760/${p})/(-${h}*1000/8.3145)] 1/K + 1/=[${t}+273.15] 1/K = 1/T<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;<br>=[ln(760/${p})/(-${h}*1000/8.3145) + 1/(${t}+273.15)] 1/K = 1/T<sub>2</sub></p>\r\n<p>Taking the inverse of both sides:<br>=[(ln(760/${p})/(-${h}*1000/8.3145) + 1/(${t}+273.15))^-1] K = T<sub>2</sub></p>"},{"group":"","stem":"<span style=\"font-size: 10.5pt;\">How much energy is required to heat ${a 30 40 3} g H<sub>2</sub>O from a liquid at ${b 40 80 3}°C to a gas at ${c 110 130}°C?<br>ΔH<sub>vap</sub> = 40.7 kJ/mol<br>C<sub>liquid</sub>&nbsp;= 4.184 <span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{J}{g°C} \\)</span>&nbsp;<br>C<sub>gas</sub> = 2.01 <span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{J}{g°C} \\)</span>&nbsp;&nbsp;<br>C<sub>solid</sub> = 2.09 <span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{J}{g°C} \\)</span>&nbsp;<br>T<sub>melting</sub> = 0°C&nbsp;<br>T<sub>boiling</sub> = 100°C<br></span>","choices":["=[(${a}*4.184/1000*(100-${b}))+(${a}/18.02*(40.7))+(${a}*2.01/1000*(${c}-100))] kJ","=[(${a}*4.184*(100-${b}))+(${a}/18.02*(40.7))+(${a}*2.01*(${c}-100))] kJ","=[(${a}*4.184/1000*(100-${b}))+(${a}*(40.7))+(${a}*2.01/1000*(${c}-100))] kJ","=[(${a}*4.184/1000*(${b}))+(${a}/18.02*(40.7))+(${a}*2.01/1000*(${c}))] kJ"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>To calculate the energy required to heat water from a liquid at ${b}°C to a gas at ${c}°C, we need to consider the following steps:</p>\r\n<ol>\r\n<li>Heating the liquid water from its initial temperature to its boiling point.</li>\r\n<li>Vaporizing the liquid water at its boiling point to gas.</li>\r\n<li>Heating the water vapor from it's boiling point to ${c}°C.</li>\r\n</ol>\r\n<p>Step 1: Heating the liquid water First, we calculate the energy required to heat the liquid water from ${b}°C to its boiling point at 100°C.</p>\r\n<p>q<sub>1</sub> = m x C<sub>liquid</sub> x ΔT<sub>1</sub></p>\r\n<p>where: q<sub>1</sub> = energy required (in joules) m = mass of water (in grams) <br>C<sub>liquid</sub> = specific heat capacity of liquid water (in J/g-°C) <br>ΔT<sub>1</sub> = change in temperature (final temperature - initial temperature)<br>C<sub>gas</sub> = specific heat capacity of liquid water (in J/g-°C)</p>\r\n<p>Given: m = ${a} g <br>C<sub>liquid</sub> = 4.184 J/g-°C <br>ΔT<sub>1</sub> = 100°C - ${b}°C = =[100-${b}]°C</p>\r\n<p>q<sub>1</sub> = (${a} g) x (4.184 J/g-°C) x (=[100-${b}]°C) <br>q<sub>1</sub> ≈ =[(100-${b})*4.184*${a}] J x <span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{1 kJ}{1000 J} \\)</span> = =[(100-${b})*4.184*${a}/1000] kJ</p>\r\n<p>Step 2: Vaporizing the liquid water Next, we calculate the energy required to vaporize the liquid water at its boiling point.</p>\r\n<p>q<sub>2</sub> = n x ΔH<sub>vap</sub></p>\r\n<p>where: q<sub>2</sub> = energy required (in joules) <br>n = number of moles of water <br>ΔH<sub>vap</sub> = enthalpy of vaporization (in J/mol)</p>\r\n<p>To calculate the number of moles of water, we use the molar mass of water (H<sub>2</sub>O), which is approximately 18.02 g/mol.</p>\r\n<p>mol = ${a} x <span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{1 mol H_2O}{18.02 g H_2O} \\)</span> ≈ =[${a}/18.02] mol</p>\r\n<p>Given: ΔH<sub>vap</sub> = 40.7 kJ/mol&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p>q<sub>2</sub> = (=[${a}/18.02] mol) * (40.7 kJ/mol) ≈ =[${a}/18.02*40.7] kJ<br><br>Step 3: Heating the water vapor, we calculate the energy required to heat the water vapor from 100°C to ${c}°C.</p>\r\n<p>q<sub>3</sub> = m x C<sub>liquid</sub> x ΔT<sub>2<br></sub></p>\r\n<p>where: q<sub>3</sub> = energy required (in J) m = mass of water (in grams) <br>C<sub>gas</sub> = specific heat capacity of liquid water (in J/g-°C) <br>ΔT<sub>1</sub> = change in temperature (final temperature - initial temperature)</p>\r\n<p>Given: m = ${a} g <br>C<sub>liquid</sub> = 2.01 J/g-°C <br>ΔT<sub>1</sub> = ${c}°C - 100°C = =[${c}-100]°C</p>\r\n<p>q<sub>3</sub> = (${a} g) x (2.01 J/g-°C) x (=[${c} - 100]°C) <br>q<sub>3</sub> ≈ =[(${c}-100)*2.01*${a}] J x <span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{1 kJ}{1000 J} \\)</span> = =[(${c}-100)*2.01*${a}/1000] kJ</p>\r\n<p>Total energy required: The total energy required is the sum of q<sub>1</sub>, q<sub>2</sub> and q<sub>3</sub>.</p>\r\n<p>Total energy = q<sub>1</sub> + ΔH<sub>hydration</sub></p>\r\n<p>Plugging in the given values:</p>\r\n<p>ΔH<sub>lattice</sub> = ${s} kJ/mol - (${h} kJ/mol) = ${s} kJ/mol + =[${s}*-1] kJ/mol = =[${s} - ${h}] kJ/mol</p>"}],"Chapter 13 (SLO)":[{"group":"","stem":"(SLO 1.1) The osmotic pressure of a solution formed by dissolving ${m 20 40 3} mg of Aspirin (C<sub>9</sub>H<sub>8</sub>O<sub>4</sub>) (180.16 g/mol) in enough water to make ${v 0.2 0.4 3} L of solution at ${t 20 40}°C is _____ atm.","choices":["=[${m}/1000/180.16/${v}*0.08206*(${t}+273.15)]","=[${m}/1000/180.16/${v}*0.08206*(${t})]","=[${m}/180.16/${v}*0.08206*(${t}+273.15)]","=[${m}/1000/180.16*0.08206*(${t}+273.15)]"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>Given: Mass of Aspirin = ${m} mg x 1 g/1000 mg= =[${m}/1000] g <br>Molar mass of Aspirin (C<sub>9</sub>H<sub>8</sub>O<sub>4</sub>) = 180.16 g/mol <br>Volume of solution (V) = ${v} L</p>\r\n<p>First, calculate the number of moles of Aspirin:</p>\r\n<p>moles of Aspirin = 0.0236 g x (1mol Aspirin)/(180.16 g Aspirin) ≈ =[${m}/1000/180.16] mol</p>\r\n<p>Next, calculate the molarity (M) of the solution:</p>\r\n<p>Molarity (M) = moles of solute / volume of solution Molarity (M) = =[${m}/10000/180.16] mol / ${v} L <br>Molarity (M) ≈ &nbsp;=[${m}/1000/180.16/${v}] M</p>\r\n<p>Now we can calculate the osmotic pressure:</p>\r\n<p>π = MRT</p>\r\n<p>where: M is the molarity of the solution R is the ideal gas constant (0.0821 L·atm/(mol·K)) T is the temperature in Kelvin (K)</p>\r\n<p>Given: Temperature (T) = ${t}°C +273.15 = =[${t}+273.15; 5] K</p>\r\n<p>π = (=[${m}/1000/180.16/${v}]) * (0.08206 L·atm/(mol·K)) * (=[${t}+273.15; 5] K) π ≈ =[${m}/1000/180.16/${v}*0.08206*(${t}+273.15)] atm</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"(SLO 1.3) The Henry’s law constant for ${carbon dioxide, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen} gas in water at 20ºC is ${392, 8.1, 7.1, 14} x 10<sup>-4</sup> M/atm. It occurs due to flaws or biases in the measurement process and leads to measurements that are consistently either higher or lower than the true value. This type of error does not average out over repeated trials and can significantly affect the accuracy of the measurements., Random error refers to unpredictable variations in measured values that can occur in any direction. It does not consistently bias measurements in one specific direction (such as always too high or too low). Random errors are typically caused by factors that introduce variability into the measurement process, such as noise, fluctuations in environmental conditions, or inherent limitations in the measurement equipment. These errors are inherent in the measurement process and cannot be eliminated completely but can be minimized through statistical analysis and repeated measurements.}</p>"},{"group":"reading measurements","stem":"Read the water level with the correct number of significant figures.&nbsp;<br><br><img title=\"graduated cylindar 2.jpg\" src=\"../images/4.jpeg\" alt=\"\" width=\"189\" height=\"282\">","choices":["67.0 mL","67 mL","67.00 mL","68.0 mL"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<ol>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Start by identifying the main intervals or markings on the graduated cylinder. For example, if the cylinder has markings every 1 mL, those are the main intervals.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Observe the position of the meniscus (the curved surface of the liquid) within the main interval. Determine if the meniscus is closer to the lower or upper marking of the interval.&nbsp; In this case the meniscus appears to be right on the 67 mL mark.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Next, mentally divide the main interval into smaller divisions. Estimate the position of the meniscus within these smaller divisions. For example, if you are estimating to one decimal place, divide the main interval into 10 equal parts.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Based on your judgment, determine the fraction or proportion of the interval that the meniscus appears to be closer to. Estimate this fraction as accurately as possible.&nbsp; In this case, it might be reasonable to estimate another 0.0 (exactly on the 67 mL mark) or 0.1 mL (just above the 67 mL mark).</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>Add the estimated fraction to the main interval reading. This will give you an estimate of the measurement with an extra significant figure.&nbsp; Reasonable estimates could include 67.0 mL or 67.1 mL, however only 67.0 is an option choice.</li>\r\n</ol>\r\nThe main concept being tested on is that you need to estimate one additional place value past what the main intervals show."},{"group":"reading measurements","stem":"Read the water level (shown in mL) with the correct number of significant figures.&nbsp;<br><br><img title=\"graduated cylindar 3.jpg\" src=\"../images/1.jpeg\" alt=\"\" width=\"151\" height=\"262\">","choices":["2.65 mL","2.6 mL","2.7 mL","2.75 mL"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<ol>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Start by identifying the main intervals or markings on the graduated cylinder. Significant figures are the digits in a number that contribute to its precision. When determining the number of significant figures, we consider the following:</p>\r\n<ol>\r\n<li>Non-zero digits are always significant.</li>\r\n<li>Leading zeros are never significant.&nbsp; There are no leading zeros in this problem.</li>\r\n<li>Captured zeros, which are zeros between non-zero digits (1 and 0), are also significant.</li>\r\n<li>Trailing zeros (the final zeros) are significant only if they are after a decimal point. In this case, since there is a decimal point, the trailing zeros would be considered significant.</li>\r\n</ol>\r\nIn this case the digits that are significant are ${a}.<br>\r\n<p>To summarize, captured zeros and non-zero digits are significant, leading zeros (zeros before the non-zero digits) are not significant, and trailing zeros (zeros after the non-zero digits) are significant if there is a decimal.&nbsp; Therefore, the measurement ${a 1 9.99 3} ${m, kg, mL, mm, cm, g, L} &nbsp;has three significant figures.</p>","nota":false},{"group":"sig figs","stem":"How many significant figures are in the measurement, 0.000${a 1 9 1}${b 0 9 1} ${m, kg, mL, mm, cm, g, L}?","choices":["2","6","4","5"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>The measurement 0.000${a 1 9 1}${b 0 9 1} ${m, kg, mL, mm, cm, g, L} has two significant figures. Significant figures are the digits in a number that contribute to its precision. When determining the number of significant figures, we consider the following:</p>\r\n<ol>\r\n<li>Non-zero digits are always significant.</li>\r\n<li>Leading zeros are never significant.&nbsp; The four zeros before ${a}${b} are not significant.&nbsp;</li>\r\n<li>Captured zeros, which are zeros between non-zero digits (1 and 0), are also significant.&nbsp; There are no captured zeros in this case.</li>\r\n<li>Trailing zeros (the final zeros) are significant only if they are after a decimal point. It involves a series of steps that include making observations, formulating a hypothesis, designing and conducting experiments or gathering data, analyzing the results, and drawing conclusions. The scientific method emphasizes the importance of empirical evidence, objective observation, and the iterative process of testing and refining hypotheses through experimentation.</p>\r\n<p>The scientific method is not directed or controlled by the government. It is a framework used by scientists from various fields. While scientific consensus is important in science, the scientific method itself is not focused on achieving consensus within the scientific community. The scientific method does not provide irrefutable facts. Instead, it aims to develop and refine scientific knowledge based on the best available evidence, which is subject to further testing and revision. Science is a self-correcting process that continually builds upon existing knowledge.</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"Which of the following statements are true?","choices":["Protons and neutrons have approximately the same mass (about 1 amu), whereas electrons have almost no mass.","Protons and electrons have approximately the same mass (about 1 amu), whereas neutrons have almost no mass.","Electrons and neutrons have approximately the same mass (about 1 amu), whereas protons have almost no mass.",""],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>The correct answer is:</p>\r\n<p><strong>Protons and neutrons have approximately the same mass (about 1 amu), whereas electrons have almost no mass.</strong></p>\r\n<p>Protons and neutrons, which are both found in the nucleus of an atom, have similar masses of approximately 1 atomic mass unit (amu). Electrons, on the other hand, have a much smaller mass compared to protons and neutrons. The mass of an electron is about 1/1836 times the mass of a proton or neutron, making it almost negligible in comparison.</p>\r\n<p>While protons and electrons have opposite charges and play crucial roles in determining the properties of atoms, they have significantly different masses. Protons are much more massive than electrons.</p>\r\n<p>Neutrons and electrons have significantly different masses. Neutrons have a mass similar to protons, while electrons have a much smaller mass.</p>","nota":false},{"group":"","stem":"The atomic number (Z) is the number of ________ found in the nucleus of an atom.","choices":["Protons","Neutrons","Electrons","Protons and neutrons"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"The atomic number (Z) is the number of protons found in the nucleus of an atom. This element has two isotopes, the lighter of which has an atomic mass of ${b 340 350 5}&nbsp; amu and an abundance of ${c 70 80 5}%. What is the mass of the heavier isotope?","choices":["=[(${a}-${b}*${c}/100)/(1-${c}/100); 5]","=[(${b}-${a}*(1-${c}/100))/(${c}/100); 5]","=[(${a}-${b}*(1-${c}/100))/(${c}/100); 5]",""],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>To find the mass of the heavier isotope, we can use the information provided. Let's denote the mass of the heavier isotope as X amu.</p>\r\n<p>The average atomic weight of the compound is calculated by considering the masses and abundances of both isotopes. Using the given values, we can set up the following equation:</p>\r\n<p>(${b} amu * =[${c}/100; 5]) + (X amu * abundance of heavier isotope) = ${a} amu</p>\r\n<p>Simplifying the equation:</p>\r\n<p>=[${b}*${c}/100; 5] amu + (X amu * abundance of heavier isotope * ) = ${a} amu</p>\r\n<p>Subtracting =[${b}*${c}/100; 5] amu from both sides:</p>\r\n<p>abundance of heavier isotope * X amu = =[${a}-(${b}*${c}/100); 5] amu</p>\r\n<p>Now, we can solve for the mass of the heavier isotope:</p>\r\n<p>X amu = =[${a}-(${b}*${c}/100); 5] amu / abundance of heavier isotope</p>\r\n<p>Given that the abundance of the heavier isotope is =[100-${c}; 5]% (100% - ${c}%), we can set up the following equation:</p>\r\n<p>X amu = =[${a}-(${b}*${c}/100); 5] amu / =[100-${c}; 5]%</p>\r\n<p>Converting the abundance to a decimal:</p>\r\n<p>X amu = =[${a}-(${b}*${c}/100); 5] amu / =[1-${c}/100; 5]</p>\r\n<p>X amu ≈ =[(${a}-${b}*${c}/100)/(1-${c}/100); 5] amu</p>","nota":false},{"group":"","stem":"When a neutral atom ${loses, gains} an electron it becomes a(n) ____________, with a _____________ charge.","choices":["${cation, anion}, ${positive, negative}","${anion, cation}, ${positive, negative}","${cation, anion}, ${negative, positive}","${anion, cation}, ${negative, positive}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"When a neutral atom ${loses, gains} an electron, it becomes a ${positively, negatively} charged ion called a ${cation, anion}. &nbsp;${Cation, Anion} have a net ${positive, negative} charge. It can be a compound or a diatomic molecule composed of the same type of atoms.</p>\r\n<p>A compound: Two or more different elements chemically bonded together. Compounds have a fixed ratio of elements and can be represented by a chemical formula.</p>\r\n<p>A heterogeneous mixture: Two or more elements or compounds that are not covalently or ionically bonded and do not have a uniform composition. In a heterogeneous mixture, the components are not evenly distributed, and their properties may vary within the mixture.</p>\r\n<p>A homogeneous mixture: Two or more elements or compounds that are not covalently or ionically bonded and have a uniform composition. In a homogeneous mixture, the components are evenly distributed throughout, and the mixture appears uniform at the macroscopic level.</p>\r\n<p>To summarize:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Atom: Fundamental unit of matter.</li>\r\n<li>Molecule: Two or more atoms covalently bonded together.</li>\r\n<li>Compound: Two or more different elements chemically bonded together.</li>\r\n<li>Heterogeneous mixture: Components are not evenly distributed and do not have a uniform composition.</li>\r\n<li>Homogeneous mixture: Components are evenly distributed and have a uniform composition.</li>\r\n</ul>"},{"group":"","stem":"Which of the following describe ${an element, a compound, a homogeneous mixture, a heterogeneous mixture}?","choices":["${A substance that can't be element: A substance that can't be chemically broken down into simpler substances. Elements are made up of only one type of atom.</p>\r\n<p>A compound: A substance composed of two or more elements in a fixed, definite proportion. Compounds are chemically bonded together and have a specific chemical formula.</p>\r\n<p>A homogeneous mixture: Two or more substances in variable proportions, where the composition is constant throughout. In a homogeneous mixture, the components are evenly distributed, and the mixture appears uniform at the macroscopic level.</p>\r\n<p>A heterogeneous mixture: Two or more substances in variable proportions, where the composition is variable throughout. In a heterogeneous mixture, the components are not evenly distributed, and the mixture may have visible variations or phases.</p>\r\n<p>To summarize:</p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>Element: Can't be chemically broken down into simpler substances.</li>\r\n<li>Compound: Composed of two or more elements in a fixed, definite proportion.</li>\r\n<li>Homogeneous mixture: Components are in variable proportions, but the composition is constant throughout. Appears uniform.</li>\r\n<li>Heterogeneous mixture: Components are in variable proportions, and the composition may vary throughout. Exhibits visible variations.</li>\r\n</ul>"},{"group":"","stem":"The statement \"${matter is composed of small indestructible particles, In a chemical reaction matter is neither created nor destroyed, if two elements form more than one compound the ratios of the masses of the second element that combine with a fixed mass of the first element will always be ratios of small whole numbers, samples of a compound will always contain the same proportion of elements by mass}\" belongs to:","choices":["${Dalton's Atomic Theory, the Law of Conservation of Mass, the Law of Multiple Proportions, the Law of Definite Proportions}","${the Law of Definite Proportions, Dalton's Atomic Theory, the Law of Conservation of Mass, the Law of Multiple Proportions}","${the Law of Multiple Proportions, the Law of Definite Proportions, Dalton's Atomic Theory, the Law of Conservation of Mass}","${the Law of Conservation of Mass, the Law of Multiple Proportions, the Law of Definite Proportions, Dalton's Atomic Theory}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>Dalton's Atomic Theory: Matter is composed of small indestructible particles.</p>\r\n<p>The Law of Conservation of Mass: In a chemical reaction, matter is neither created nor destroyed.</p>\r\n<p>The Law of Multiple Proportions: If two elements form more than one compound, the ratios of the masses of the second element that combine with a fixed mass of the first element will always be ratios of small whole numbers.</p>\r\n<p>The Law of Definite Proportions: Samples of a compound will always contain the same proportion of elements by mass.</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"What is the charge, and approximate mass of protons, neutrons, and electrons?","choices":["protons: +1 charge &amp; 1 amu; neutron: no charge &amp; 1 amu; electron: -1 charge &amp; 0 amu","protons: +1 charge &amp; 1 amu; neutron: -1 charge &amp; 0 amu; electron: no charge &amp; 1 amu","protons: -1 charge &amp; 0 amu; neutron: no charge &amp; 1 amu; electron: +1 charge &amp; 1 amu","protons: no charge &amp; 1 amu; neutron: -1 charge &amp; 0 amu; electron: +1 charge &amp; 1 amu"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>Protons: Protons carry a positive charge of +1 and are located in the nucleus of an atom. The approximate mass of a proton is 1.67 x 10^-27 kilograms or 1 atomic mass unit (amu).</p>\r\n<p>Neutrons: Neutrons are electrically neutral, meaning they have no charge. Like protons, they are located in the nucleus of an atom. The approximate mass of a neutron is also 1.67 x 10^-27 kilograms or 1 atomic mass unit (amu), which is very similar to the mass of a proton.</p>\r\n<p>Electrons: Electrons carry a negative charge of -1 and orbit around the nucleus of an atom in electron shells. The mass of an electron is much smaller compared to protons and neutrons. It is typically a one- or two-letter abbreviation, such as H for hydrogen, C for carbon, or Au for gold.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Determine the atomic number: The atomic number of an element corresponds to the number of protons in the nucleus of its atoms. It is usually listed as a subscript to the left of the chemical symbol. You can find the atomic number on the periodic table.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Calculate the mass number: The number of neutrons is given. Add this number to the atomic number to determine the mass number. The mass number represents the total number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Write the isotope: Once you know the atomic number and the number of neutrons, you can write the isotope by combining the chemical symbol, atomic number, and mass number. The atomic number is written as a subscript, and the mass number is written as a superscript.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n</ol>\r\n<p>In this problem:</p>\r\n<ol>\r\n<li>The chemical symbol is ${Cr, Mg, Ca, Ti, Fe}.</li>\r\n<li>The atomic number of ${chromium, magnesium, calcium, titanium, iron} is ${24, 12, 20, 22, 26}.</li>\r\n<li>Add the number of neutrons (=[${28, 12, 20, 25, 33}+${a}; 2] neutrons) to the atomic number (${24, 12, 20, 22, 26}) to determine the mass number: =[${28, 12, 20, 25, 33}+${a}; 2] + ${24, 12, 20, 22, 26} = =[${28, 12, 20, 25, 33}+${a}+${24, 12, 20, 22, 26}; 2].</li>\r\n<li>Write the isotope: ${Chromium-, Magnesium-, Calcium-, Titanium-, Iron-}=[${24, 12, 20, 22, 26}+${28, 12, 20, 25, 33}+${a}; 2]</li>\r\n</ol>"},{"group":"","stem":"In the following isotope symbol, the letters for the element have been replaced with an X.&nbsp; What is the name of the isotope?<br><span class=\"math-tex\">\\( ^{${12, 13, 14, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19}}_{${6, 6, 6, 7, 7, 8, 8, 9, 9}}X \\)</span>","choices":["${Carbon-12, Carbon-13, Carbon-14, Nitrogen-14, Nitrogen-15, Oxygen-16, Oxygen-17, Fluorine-18, Fluorine-19}","${Carbon-6, Carbon-6, Carbon-6, Nitrogen-7, Nitrogen-7, Oxygen-8, Oxygen-8, Fluorine-9, Fluorine-9}","${Carbon-7, Carbon-7, Carbon-8, Nitrogen-8, Nitrogen-8, Oxygen-9, Oxygen-9, Fluorine-9, Fluorine-9}","${Magnesium-12, Aluminum-13, Oxygen-8, Oxygen-8, Oxygen-8, Phosphorous-15, Sulfur-16, Argon-18, Potassium-19}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>The correct answer is ${Carbon-12, Carbon-13, Carbon-14, Nitrogen-14, Nitrogen-15, Oxygen-16, Oxygen-17, Fluorine-18, Fluorine-19}.</p>\r\n<p>In the isotope symbol <span class=\"math-tex\">\\( ^{${12, 13, 14, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19}}_{${6, 6, 6, 7, 7, 8, 8, 9, 9}}X \\)</span>, the superscript ${12, 13, 14, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19} represents the mass number, which is the sum of protons and neutrons in the nucleus. 58.69, 197}/1000] mol</p>\r\n<p>Next, we'll calculate the number of atoms: number of atoms = moles × Avogadro's number number of atoms = =[${a}/${54.94, 55.85, 58.69, 197}/1000] mol × <span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{6.022 × 10^{23} atoms}{1 mol} \\)</span></p>\r\n<p>Calculating the above expression, we get: number of atoms ≈ =[${a}/${54.94, 55.85, 58.69, 197}*6.022*10^23/1000] atoms</p>"}],"Chapter 2":[{"group":"","stem":"What is the ${vertical height of a wave, number of waves that pass through a stationary point per second, distance between adjacent crests of a wave} called?","choices":["${amplitude, frequency, wavelength, wavediameter}","${wavediameter, amplitude, frequency, wavelength}","${wavelength, wavediameter, amplitude, frequency}","${frequency, wavelength, wavediameter, amplitude}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>Frequency: Frequency refers to the number of complete cycles or oscillations of a wave that occur in one second. It is typically measured in hertz (Hz) and represents how many times a wave repeats per second.</p>\r\n<p>Wavelength: Wavelength is the distance between two consecutive corresponding points on a wave, such as from peak to peak or trough to trough. It is usually represented by the Greek letter lambda (λ) and is measured in units such as meters (m), nanometers (nm), or angstroms (Å), depending on the scale of the wave.</p>\r\n<p>Amplitude: Amplitude represents the maximum displacement or distance from the equilibrium position of a wave. In other words, it measures the intensity or strength of a wave. For example, in a transverse wave, it refers to the distance from the baseline to the peak or trough of the wave. It can indicate the brightness or loudness of a wave, depending on the type of wave. Amplitude is typically measured in units such as meters (m) or volts (V).<br><br>Wavediameter is a made-up term.</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"Which of the following colors has the ${longest wavelength, lowest frequency, highest frequency, lowest wavelength, }","choices":["${red, red, violet, violet}","${violet, violet, red, red}","${orange, yellow, green, blue}","${yellow, green, blue, orange}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"ROY G. BIV is a mnemonic for remembering the order of visible light from lowest energy, lowest frequency to highest energy and highest frequency or from longest wavelength to shortest wavelength.<br><br>Lowest energy, lowest frequency, highest wavelength<br>Red<br>Orange<br>Yellow<br>Green<br>Blue<br>Indigo<br>Violet<br>Highest energy, highest frequency, shortest (longest wavelength) waves."},{"group":"wave behavior","stem":"What is it called when two waves of equal amplitude that are ${in, out of} phase interact?","choices":["${constructive interference, destructive interference, diffraction, refraction}","${destructive interference, diffraction, refraction, constructive interference}","${diffraction, refraction, constructive interference, destructive interference}","${refraction, constructive interference, destructive interference, diffraction}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"When two waves of equal amplitude that are in phase interact, it is called constructive interference. In constructive interference, the waves combine to produce a resulting wave with an increased amplitude. This occurs when the peaks of one wave align with the peaks of the other wave, or the troughs align with the troughs, leading to reinforcement and an overall amplification of the wave.<br><br>When two waves of equal amplitude that are out of phase interact, it is called destructive interference. In destructive interference, the waves combine in a way that their crests align with the troughs, resulting in a canceling out or reduction of the overall amplitude. This occurs when the peaks of one wave align with the troughs of the other wave, leading to a net decrease in amplitude or even complete cancellation of the wave."},{"group":"wave behavior","stem":"One of the wave behaviors exhibited by light waves is that they will bend around an obstacle or slit comparable in size to their wavelength.&nbsp; What is this characteristic called?","choices":["diffraction","interference","effusion","refraction"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"The characteristic of light waves bending around an obstacle or slit comparable in size to their wavelength is called <strong>diffraction</strong>. Diffraction is a wave phenomenon that occurs when waves encounter an obstacle or pass through an opening and exhibit bending or spreading out.&nbsp;<br><br>\r\n<p><strong>Interference</strong>: Interference is a phenomenon that occurs when two or more waves meet and interact with each other. It results in the superposition of the waves, leading to the formation of regions of constructive and destructive interference. In regions of constructive interference, the waves reinforce each other, resulting in an increase in amplitude. In regions of destructive interference, the waves cancel each other out, leading to a decrease in amplitude.</p>\r\n<p><strong>Refraction</strong>: Refraction is the bending of waves as they pass from one medium to another, caused by a change in the speed of the waves. When a wave encounters a boundary between two mediums with different optical densities, such as air and water or air and glass, the change in speed causes the wave to change direction. This change in direction is known as refraction. Refraction is responsible for various phenomena, such as the bending of light rays in lenses, the formation of rainbows, and the apparent shift of objects when viewed through a medium.</p>\r\n<p><strong>Effusion</strong>: Effusion refers to the process by which gas molecules escape from a container through a small opening. It occurs due to the random motion and high kinetic energy of gas molecules. Effusion is governed by Graham's law, which states that the rate of effusion of a gas is inversely proportional to the square root of its molar mass. This means that lighter gas molecules effuse faster than heavier ones. Effusion plays a role in various applications, such as gas separation techniques and the operation of gas diffusion pumps.</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"Calculate the wavelength (in nm) of light that has a frequency of ${a 4.00 6.99 3} x 10<sup>14</sup> Hz.","choices":["=[(3*10^8*10^9)/(${a}*10^14)] nm","=[(3*10^8)/(${a}*10^14)] nm","=[(${a}*10^14)/(3*10^8*10^9)] nm","=[(${a}*10^14)/(3*10^8)*10000000] nm"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>To calculate the wavelength (λ) of light, you can use the equation:</p>\r\n<p>λ = c / ν</p>\r\n<p>where λ is the wavelength, c is the speed of light in a vacuum (approximately 3.00 x 10<sup>8</sup> m/s), and ν is the frequency of the light.</p>\r\n<p>First, let's convert the frequency given in Hz to 1/s since Hz and 1/s&nbsp;mean the same thing</p>\r\n<p>Frequency (ν) = ${a} x 10<sup>14</sup> Hz = ${a} x 10<sup>14</sup> 1/s</p>\r\n<p>Now, we can calculate the wavelength using the equation:</p>\r\n<p>λ = c / ν = (3.00 x 108 m/s) / (${a} x 10<sup>14</sup> 1/s)</p>\r\n<p>λ = =[(3*10^8)/(${a}*10^14)] m</p>\r\n<p>To convert this to nanometers (nm), we multiply by 10^9:</p>\r\n<p>λ = =[(3*10^8)/(${a}*10^14)] m x = <span x 10<sup>14</sup> Hz.","choices":["=[${a}*10^14*6.626*10^-34] J","=[${a}*10^14/6.626*10^-34] J","=[6.626*10^-34/${a}*10^14] J","=[6.626*10^-34/(${a}*10^14)] J"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>The frequency of the photon.</p>\r\n<p>Given the frequency:</p>\r\n<p>ν = ${a} x 10<sup>14</sup> Hz</p>\r\n<p>We can calculate the energy using the equation:</p>\r\n<p>E = (6.626 x 10<sup>-34</sup> J·s) * decreases}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>When the wavelength of a photon increases, the frequency of the photon decreases. This is because wavelength and frequency are inversely proportional to each other according to the equation:</p>\r\n<p>c = λν</p>\r\n<p>where c is the speed of light, λ is the wavelength, and ν is the frequency.</p>\r\n<p>As a result of the inverse relationship between wavelength and frequency, the energy of the photon also decreases when the wavelength increases. This is because energy is directly proportional to frequency according to the equation:</p>\r\n<p>E = hν</p>\r\n<p>where E is the energy of the photon and h is Planck's constant.</p>\r\n<p>In summary, when the wavelength of a photon increases, the frequency decreases, and consequently, the energy of the photon decreases as well.</p>"},{"group":"wavelength, frequency & energy","stem":"Which of the following happens when the ${frequency, energy} of a photon increases?","choices":["The wavelength decreases","The wavelength increases","The wavelength stays the same","The speed ${increases, decreases}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>When the frequency and energy of a photon increase, the wavelength of the photon decreases. This relationship is a consequence of the wave-particle duality of light.</p>\r\n<p>The relationship between wavelength (λ), frequency (ν), and speed of light (c) is given by the equation:</p>\r\n<p>c = λν</p>\r\n<p>As frequency increases, the wavelength decreases proportionally to maintain the constant speed of light. Similarly, energy (E) of a photon is directly proportional to its frequency (ν) according to the equation:</p>\r\n<p>E = hν</p>\r\n<p>where h is Planck's constant.</p>\r\n<p>Therefore, when the frequency and energy of a photon increase, the wavelength of the photon decreases. This relationship holds true for electromagnetic waves across the entire electromagnetic spectrum.</p>"},{"group":"wavelength, frequency & energy","stem":"Which of the following happens when the ${frequency, energy} of a photon increases?","choices":["The wavelength increases","The ${energy, frequency} increases","The ${energy, wavelength} stays the same","The speed ${increases, decreases}"],"correct":["1"],"solution":"<p>When the ${frequency, energy} of a photon increases, the ${energy, frequency} of the photon also increases. This relationship is described by the equation:</p>\r\n<p>E = hν</p>\r\n<p>where E represents the energy of the photon, h is Planck's constant (a fundamental constant of nature), and ν is the frequency of the photon.</p>\r\n<p>According to this equation, the energy of a photon is directly proportional to its frequency. As the frequency increases, the energy of the photon increases proportionally. This relationship is a fundamental concept in quantum mechanics and is known as the energy-frequency relationship.</p>\r\n<p>It's important to note that the energy of a photon is quantized, meaning it can only exist in discrete amounts or \"quanta.\" Each quantum of energy is associated with a specific frequency of the photon. (n-1)).</li>\r\n<li>m<sub>ℓ</sub> = ${+, -}=[${c}-${0, 1}; 1] (valid as it is within the range of -ℓ to +ℓ).</li>\r\n<li>m<sub>s</sub> = ${-, +}<span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{1}{2} \\)</span> (valid as it is either +1/2 or -1/2).</li>\r\n<li>Therefore, this set of quantum numbers is <strong>not valid</strong> due to the value for ℓ.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n(${e}, =[${e}-${f 1 2 1}; 1], ${-, +}=[${e}; 1], ${+, -}<span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{1}{2} \\)</span>)&nbsp;<br>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li style=\"list-style-type: none;\">\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>n = ${e} (valid as it is a positive integer).</li>\r\n<li>ℓ = =[${e}-${f}; 1] (valid as it is within the range of 0 to (n-1)).</li>\r\n<li>m<sub>ℓ</sub> = ${-, +}=[${e}; 1] (invalid as it must be within the range of -ℓ to +ℓ).</li>\r\n<li>m<sub>s</sub> = ${+, -}<span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{1}{2} \\)</span>(valid as it is either +1/2 or -1/2).</li>\r\n<li>Therefore, this set of quantum numbers is <strong>not valid</strong> due to the value of m<sub>ℓ</sub> being outside the allowed range.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n(${g}, =[${g}-${h 1 2 1}; 1], ${+, -}=[${g}-${h}; 1], ${+, -} 1)<br>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li relationships between the quantum numbers, only the set (${a}, =[${a}-${b 1 2 1}; 1], ${+, -}=[${a}-${b}; 1], ${+, -}<span class=\"math-tex\">\\( \\frac{1}{2} \\)</span>) satisfies the required <strong>spherical </strong>in shape and symmetrical around the nucleus. It has a <strong>single lobe</strong> without any nodal planes.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>p Orbitals: The p orbitals have a <strong>dumbbell shape</strong>. There are three p orbitals, designated as px, py, and pz. Each p orbital has <strong>two lobes</strong> on opposite sides of the nucleus and is oriented along the x, y, and z axes, respectively.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>d Orbitals: The d orbitals have <strong>complex shapes</strong>. There are five d orbitals, designated as dxy, dxz, dyz, dx^2-y^2, and dz^2. They have a combination of different lobes and nodal planes, resulting in various shapes.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>f Orbitals: The f orbitals also have <strong>complex shapes</strong>. These orbitals have even more intricate lobes, nodal surfaces, and orientations compared to the other orbitals.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n</ol>\r\n<p>It's important to note that these orbital shapes represent the probability distribution of finding an electron within a specific orbital, rather than the exact path of the electron.</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"According to the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, which of the following is true?","choices":["It is not possible to accurately determine both the position and momentum of an electron at the same time.","${Two electrons cannot have the same spin., Two electrons cannot occupy the same orbital at the same time.}","${It is impossible to determine the charge of a single electron., The maximum number of electrons in a hydrogen atom is one}","${There are no electron shells above 4., It is impossible to determine which electron shell an electron is in.}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>It is not possible to accurately determine both the position and momentum of an electron at the same time.</p>\r\n<p>According to the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, there is a fundamental limit to the precision with which certain pairs of physical properties of a particle, such as position and momentum, can be known simultaneously. The principle states that the more precisely the position of a particle is known, the less precisely its momentum can be known, and vice versa. This principle applies to all particles, including electrons. Therefore, it is not possible to accurately determine both the position and momentum of an electron simultaneously.</p>"}],"Chapter 3":[{"group":"","stem":"Predict the charge that ${sodium, magnesium, aluminum, nitrogen, oxygen, fluorine} will take as an ion.","choices":["${+1, +2, +3, -3, -2, -1}","${-1, +1, +2, +3, -3, -2}","${-2, -1, +1, +2, +3, -3}","${-3, -2, -1, +1, +2, +3}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>The charges that elements can form as ions depend on their position in the periodic table and their tendency to gain or lose electrons to achieve a stable electron configuration.</p>\r\n<p>Sodium (Na) tends to lose one electron to achieve a stable electron configuration, forming a +1 ion (Na<sup>+</sup>). principle, Hund's rule, Aufbau principle, Heisenberg uncertainty principle}","${Hund's rule, Aufbau principle, Heisenberg uncertainty principle, Pauli exclusion principle}","${Aufbau principle, Heisenberg uncertainty principle, Pauli exclusion principle, Hund's rule}","${Heisenberg uncertainty principle, Pauli exclusion principle, Hund's rule, Aufbau principle}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<ol>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Pauli Exclusion Principle: This principle states that no two electrons in an atom can have the same set of four quantum numbers (n, l, ml, ms). In other words, each electron in an atom must have a unique combination of quantum numbers.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Hund's Rule: According to Hund's Rule, when filling degenerate orbitals (orbitals with the same energy), electrons will occupy separate orbitals with parallel spins before pairing up with opposite spins. This rule ensures that electrons maximize their overall stability.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Aufbau Principle: The Aufbau Principle states that electrons fill the lowest energy orbitals available before moving to higher energy orbitals. Electrons will occupy orbitals in order of increasing energy, following the order of the periodic table.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle: The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle states that it is not possible to simultaneously determine the exact position and momentum (or velocity) of an electron with absolute precision. There is an inherent uncertainty in measuring these two properties, and the more precisely one property is known, the less precisely the other can be determined.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n</ol>"},{"group":"","stem":"Which of the following represents ${a ground state nitrogen atom, a violation of the Pauli exclusion principle, a violation of Hund's rule, a src=\"../images/7.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"303\" height=\"88\">&nbsp;<br>Excited state: <img title=\"ee.png\" src=\"../images/8.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"302\" height=\"83\"><br><br></p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Ground State: The ground state refers to the lowest energy state of an atom or a molecule. In the ground state, electrons occupy the available orbitals starting from the lowest energy level (n = 1) and follow the rules of the Pauli Exclusion Principle and Hund's Rule.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Violation of the Pauli Exclusion Principle: The Pauli Exclusion Principle states that no two electrons in an atom can have the same set of quantum numbers. If there is a violation of this principle, it means that two or more electrons in an atom or a system have the same quantum numbers, which is not allowed.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Violation of Hund's Rule: Hund's Rule states that when electrons occupy degenerate orbitals (orbitals with the same energy), they tend to occupy separate orbitals with parallel spins before pairing up with opposite spins. A violation of Hund's Rule occurs when electrons in degenerate orbitals pair up with opposite spins before all the orbitals are singly occupied.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Excited State: An excited state refers to any energy state of an atom or a molecule that is higher in energy than the ground state. In an excited state, one or more electrons have absorbed energy and moved to higher energy levels or different orbitals. Electrons in excited states have configurations that deviate from the ground state electron configuration. Excited states are temporary and unstable, and electrons tend to return to lower energy levels or the ground state by releasing energy in the form of photons.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n</ul>"},{"group":"penetration","stem":"An orbital that penetrates into the region occupied by core electrons is ${less, more} shielded from nuclear charge.","choices":["${True, False}","${False, True}","",""],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>An orbital that penetrates into the region occupied by core electrons is less shielded from nuclear charge. Shielding refers to the phenomenon where electrons in inner energy levels (core electrons) partially shield or screen the outer electrons from the full attraction of the positive charge of the nucleus.</p>\r\n<p>When an orbital penetrates into the region occupied by core electrons, it means that the electron spends more time closer to the nucleus. As a result, it experiences a stronger attraction to the positive charge of the nucleus. This reduces the shielding effect provided by the core electrons, making the electron in the penetrating orbital less shielded from the nuclear charge. Consequently, the electron in the penetrating orbital experiences a higher effective nuclear charge or electrostatic attraction from the nucleus compared to an electron in a non-penetrating orbital.</p>"},{"group":"penetration","stem":"An orbital that penetrates into the region occupied by core electrons will be at a ${lower, higher} energy level.","choices":["${True, False}","${False, True}","",""],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>An orbital that penetrates into the region occupied by core electrons will generally be at a lower energy level.</p>\r\n<p>The energy level of an orbital is determined by its distance from the nucleus and the effective nuclear charge experienced by the electron. When an orbital penetrates into the region occupied by core electrons, it means that the electron spends more time closer to the nucleus. As a result, it experiences a stronger attraction to the positive charge of the nucleus, leading to a lower energy level.</p>\r\n<p>In multi-electron atoms, the energy levels of orbitals can be affected by various factors, including electron-electron repulsions and shielding effects. However, in general, an orbital that penetrates into the region occupied by core electrons will have a lower energy level compared to an orbital that does not penetrate into the core region.</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"Which ground-state element has the following electron configuration?<br>1s<sup>2</sup> 2s<sup>2</sup> 2p<sup>6</sup> 3s<sup>2</sup> 3p<sup>6</sup> 4s<sup>2</sup> 3d<sup>10</sup> ${4p<sup>3</sup>, 4p<sup>1</sup>, 4p<sup>2</sup>, 4p<sup>4</sup>}","choices":["${arsenic, gallium, germanium, selenium}","${antimony, indium, tin, tellurium}","${phosphorous, aluminium, silicon, sulfur}","${vanadium, scandium, titanium, chromium}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>The electron configurations of ${arsenic, gallium, germanium, selenium} is 1s<sup>2</sup> 2s<sup>2</sup> 2p<sup>6</sup> 3s<sup>2</sup> 3p<sup>6</sup> 4s<sup>2</sup> 3d<sup>10</sup> ${4p<sup>3</sup>, 4p<sup>1</sup>, 4p<sup>2</sup>, 4p<sup>4</sup>}</p>\r\n<p>These electron configurations represent the distribution of electrons in the energy levels (shells) and orbitals of the atoms. between two non-metals, A bond between a metal and a non-metal}","${A bond between two metals, A bond between a metal and a polyatomic ion}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"A covalent bond is formed when two atoms share electrons in order to achieve a stable electron configuration. In a covalent bond, the atoms involved have similar electronegativity, meaning they have similar tendencies to attract electrons. This sharing of electrons allows both atoms to fill their outermost energy levels and achieve greater stability.<br><br>An ionic bond is formed when electrons are transferred from one atom to another, resulting in the formation of ions. In an ionic bond, one atom donates electrons to another atom, resulting in the formation of a positively charged ion (cation) and a negatively charged ion (anion). The attraction between these opposite charges holds the ions together and forms an ionic bond."},{"group":"","stem":"What is the empirical formula for ${Hg<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub>, N<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub>, CO<sub>2</sub>}?","choices":["${HgNO<sub>3</sub>, CH<sub>2</sub>O, NH<sub>3</sub>, CO<sub>2</sub>}","${Hg<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub>, N<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub>, C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>}","${Hg(NO)<sub>3</sub>, C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>6</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, N<sub>2</sub>H<sub>3</sub>, CO}","${Hg<sub>2</sub>NO<sub>6</sub>, C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>4</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, N<sub>3</sub>H, C<sub>2</sub>O}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"An empirical formula represents the simplest ratio of elements present in a compound. Since ${ammonium hydrogen sulfate (or ammonium bisulfate), magnesium hydroxide, potassium dichromate, sodium acetate} contains a polyatomic ion, it is an ionic compound.&nbsp; Therefore, to get the formula you must balance the charges of the two ions. ${Ammonium, Magnesium, Potassium, Sodium} will carry a ${+1, +2, +1, +1}, whereas&nbsp; ${hydrogen sulfate (or bisulfate), hydroxide, dichromate, acetate} will carry a ${-1, -1, -2, -1} charge.&nbsp; The lowest common multiple of ${1, 2, 1, 1} and ${1, 1, 2, 1} is ${1, 2, 2, 1}, therefore there will need to be ${1, 1, 2, 1} ${ammonium, magnesium, potassium, sodium} ions and ${1, 2, 1, 1} ${hydrogen sulfate (or bisulfate), hydroxide, dichromate, acetate} ions.&nbsp; That gives us a formula of: ${NH<sub>4</sub>HSO<sub>4</sub>, Mg(OH)<sub>2</sub>, K<sub>2</sub>Cr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>, NaC<sub>2</sub>H<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>}."},{"group":"","stem":"Determine the name for ${CoCl<sub>2</sub><span class=\"header-char\"><strong>·</strong>6H<sub>2</sub>O, CaCl<sub>2</sub><strong>·</strong>2H<sub>2</sub>O, NaC<sub>2</sub>H<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub><strong>·</strong>3H<sub>2</sub>O, FePO<sub>4</sub><strong>·</strong>4H<sub>2</sub>O}</span>","choices":["${Cobolt (II) chloride hexahydrate, Calcium chloride dihydrate, Sodium acetate trihydrate, Iron (III) phosphate tetrahydrate}","${Cobolt chloride hexahydrate, Calcium (II) chloride dihydrate, Sodium (I) acetate trihydrate, Iron phosphate tetrahydrate}","${Cobolt (II) chloride heptahydrate, Calcium chloride bihydrate, Sodium acetate tetrahydrate, Iron (III) phosphate trihydrate}","${Cobolt (II) chloride, Calcium chloride diaquate, Sodium acetate dihydrogen monoxide, Iron (III) phosphate quadhydrate}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"${CoCl<sub>2</sub><span class=\"header-char\"><strong>·</strong>6H<sub>2</sub>O, CaCl<sub>2</sub><strong>·</strong>2H<sub>2</sub>O, NaC<sub>2</sub>H<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub><strong>·</strong>3H<sub>2</sub>O, FePO<sub>4</sub><strong>·</strong>4H<sub>2</sub>O} is an ionic compound and a hydrate.&nbsp; This means that for every 3 moles of KBr, we can expect 1 mole of FeBr<sub>3</sub> to be formed.</p>\r\n<p>Given that we have ${a} moles of KBr, we can calculate the moles of FeBr<sub>3</sub> using the stoichiometric ratio:</p>\r\n<p>Moles of FeBr3 = (${a} moles of KBr) / (3 moles of KBr per 1 mole of FeBr<sub>3</sub>) Moles of FeBr3 = ${a} moles / 3 Moles of FeBr3 = =[${a}/3] moles</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"How many grams of LiF can be formed from ${a 1.0 4.0 3} moles of BF<sub>3</sub>? of H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> to moles and then use the balanced chemical equation to determine the stoichiometric ratio.</p>\r\n<p>First, we calculate the moles of H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>: <br>Molar mass of H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> = 2(1.01 g/mol of H) + 12.01 g/mol of C + 3(16.00 g/mol of O) = 62.03 g/mol <br>Moles of H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> = Mass of H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> / Molar mass of H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> Moles of H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> = ${a} g / 62.03 g/mol Moles of H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> ≈ =[${a}/62.03] moles</p>\r\n<p>From the balanced chemical equation: 2 KNO<sub>3</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> ➞ K<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> + 2 HNO<sub>3</sub></p>\r\n<p>The stoichiometric ratio between H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> and KNO<sub>3</sub> is 1:2. This means that 1 mole of H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> will react with 2 moles of KNO<sub>3</sub>.</p>\r\n<p>Therefore, the moles of KNO<sub>3</sub> that will react with ${a} moles of H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> is:</p>\r\n<p>Moles of KNO<sub>3</sub> = 2 × Moles of H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub></p>\r\n<p>Moles of KNO<sub>3</sub> = 2 × =[${a}/62.03] moles Moles of KNO<sub>3</sub> ≈ =[${a}/62.03*2] moles</p>\r\n<p>Finally, we calculate the grams of KNO<sub>3</sub> using its molar mass: Molar mass of KNO<sub>3</sub> = 39.10 g/mol + 14.01 g/mol + 3(16.00 g/mol) = 101.10 g/mol <br>Grams of KNO<sub>3</sub> = Moles of KNO<sub>3</sub> × Molar mass of KNO<sub>3</sub> <br>Grams of KNO<sub>3</sub> = =[${a}/62.03*2] moles × 101.10 g/mol <br>Grams of KNO3 ≈ =[${a}/62.03*2*101.1] g</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"How many molecules of water can be produced when ${a 10.0 20.0 3} g of CH<sub>4</sub>&nbsp;reacts with excess oxygen?\r\n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">CH<sub>4</sub> + 2 O<sub>2</sub> ➞ CO<sub>2</sub> + 2 H<sub>2</sub>O</div>","choices":["=[${a}/16.05*2*6.022*(10^23)] molecules","=[${a}/16.05*2*18.02] molecules","=[${a}/16.05/2*6.022*(10^23)] molecules","=[${a}/18.02/2*6.022*(10^23)] molecules"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>First, calculate the moles of CH<sub>4</sub> using its molar mass: <br>Molar mass of CH<sub>4</sub> = 12.01 g/mol + 4(1.01 g/mol) = 16.05 g/mol</p>\r\n<p>Moles of CH<sub>4</sub> = Mass of CH<sub>4</sub> / Molar mass of CH<sub>4</sub> <br>Moles of CH4 = ${a} g / 16.05 g/mol Moles of CH4 ≈ =[${a}/16.05] moles</p>\r\n<p>From the balanced equation: CH<sub>4</sub> + 2 O<sub>2</sub> ➞ CO<sub>2</sub> + 2 H<sub>2</sub>O</p>\r\n<p>The stoichiometric ratio between CH<sub>4</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>O is 1:2. This means that 1 mole of CH<sub>4</sub> will produce 2 moles of H<sub>2</sub>O.</p>\r\n<p>Moles of H<sub>2</sub>O = 2 × Moles of CH<sub>4</sub> <br>Moles of H<sub>2</sub>O = 2 × =[${a}/16.05] moles <br>Moles of H<sub>2</sub>O ≈ =[${a}/16.05*2] moles</p>\r\n<p>Finally, convert the moles of water to molecules using Avogadro's number (6.022 × 10<sup>23</sup> molecules/mol):</p>\r\n<p>Number of water molecules = Moles of H<sub>2</sub>O × Avogadro's number Number of water molecules <br>= =[${a}/16.05*2] moles × (6.022 × 10<sup>23</sup> molecules/mol) <br>Number of water molecules ≈ =[${a}/16.05*2*6.022*(10^23)] molecules</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"What is the theoretical yield, in moles of CO<sub>2</sub>, from the reaction of ${a 10 20 3} moles of C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub> with ${b 10 33 3} moles of O<sub>2</sub>?\r\n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">2 C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub> + 7 O<sub>2</sub> ➞ 4 CO<sub>2</sub> + 6 H<sub>2</sub>O</div>","choices":["=[${b}/7*4] moles","=[${b}*7/4] moles","=[${a}/7*4] moles","=[${a}/2*4] moles"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>To determine the theoretical yield of CO<sub>2</sub>, we need to compare the moles of C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub> and O<sub>2</sub> and their respective stoichiometric coefficients in the balanced equation. The reactant that produces the least amount of CO<sub>2</sub> based on the stoichiometry will limit the amount of CO<sub>2</sub> produced.</p>\r\n<p>From the balanced equation: 2 C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub> + 7 O<sub>2</sub> ➞ 4 CO<sub>2</sub> + 6 H<sub>2</sub>O</p>\r\n<p>Moles of C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub> = ${a} moles <br>Moles of O<sub>2</sub> = ${b} moles</p>\r\n<p>To determine the limiting reactant, we compare the the amounts of product we can produce from each reactant.</p>\r\n<p>The stoichiometric ratio between C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub> and CO<sub>2</sub> is 2:4. This means that 2 moles of C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub>&nbsp;react to produce 4 moles of CO<sub>2</sub>.</p>\r\n<p>The theoretical yield of CO<sub>2</sub> based on the C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub> being the limiting reagent: Moles of limiting reactant (C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub>) × Stoichiometric coefficient of CO<sub>2</sub> = ${a} moles × (4 mol CO<sub>2</sub> / 2 mol C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub>) = =[${a}*4/2] moles CO<sub>2<br></sub><br>The stoichiometric ratio between O<sub>2</sub> and CO<sub>2</sub> is 7:4. This means that 7 moles of O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;react to produce 4 moles of CO<sub>2</sub>.</p>\r\n<p>The theoretical yield of CO<sub>2</sub> based on the O<sub>2</sub> being the limiting reagent: Moles of limiting reactant (O<sub>2</sub>) × Stoichiometric coefficient of CO<sub>2</sub> = ${b} moles × (4 mol CO<sub>2</sub> / 7 mol O<sub>2</sub>) = =[${b}*4/7] moles CO<sub>2</sub></p>\r\n<p>Since assuming O<sub>2</sub> is the limiting reagent produces a lower yield, O<sub>2</sub> is actually our limiting reactant.&nbsp;&nbsp;<br><br>Therefore, the theoretical yield of CO<sub>2</sub> from the given reaction is approximately =[${b}*4/7] moles CO<sub>2</sub>.</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"What is the limiting reactant when ${a 10 14 3} moles of ZnS react with ${b 10.0 18 3} moles of AlP?\r\n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">3 ZnS + 2 AlP ➞ Zn<sub>3</sub>P<sub>2</sub> + Al<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub></div>","choices":["ZnS","AlP","Zn<sub>3</sub>P<sub>2</sub>","Al<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>To determine the limiting reactant, we need to compare the moles of each product we could produce from the moles of each reactant, assuming the other reactant is in excess.&nbsp; The reactant that produces fewer moles of product will be the limiting reactant.</p>\r\n<p>From the balanced equation: 3 ZnS + 2 AlP ➞ Zn<sub>3</sub>P<sub>2</sub> + Al<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub></p>\r\n<p>The stoichiometric ratio between ZnS and AlP is 3:2. smallest} difference in electronegativity. Generally speaking the elements with the ${largest, smallest} difference in electronegativity will be ${furthest, closest} on the periodic table.&nbsp; However, you should remember that hydrogen has an electronegativity that is around that of metalloids.&nbsp; In other words, it is low for a nonmetal."},{"group":"dipole moment/ionic character","stem":"Which compound has the <strong>${largest, smallest}</strong> ionic character in the gas phase?","choices":["${LiF, Cl<sub>2</sub>}","${Cl<sub>2</sub>, LiF}","${ClF, CO}","${HF, HCl}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"The compound with the ${largest, smallest} ionic character will be the one with the ${largest, smallest} dipole.<br><br>The ${largest, smallest} dipole moment will be between the two elements that have the ${largest, smallest} difference in electronegativity. The overall charge of the ion is -2 as well. Since the sum of the oxidation states in an ion must equal the overall charge, we can calculate the oxidation state of sulfur.</p>\r\n<p>Let's assume the oxidation state of sulfur as x. We have four oxygen atoms, each with an oxidation state of -2. Therefore:</p>\r\n<p>(x) + 4(-2) = -2</p>\r\n<p>Simplifying the equation:</p>\r\n<p>x - 8 = -2</p>\r\n<p>x = +6</p>"},{"group":"oxidation state","stem":"What is the oxidation state of P in PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3-</sup>?","choices":["+5","+7","+3","+1"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>To determine the oxidation state of phosphorus in PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3-</sup>, we consider the overall charge of the ion and the known oxidation states of other elements involved.</p>\r\n<p>In the phosphate ion (PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3-</sup>), the oxygen atoms have a known oxidation state of -2. The overall charge of the ion is -3. The overall charge of the ion is -2 as well. Since the sum of the oxidation states in an ion must equal the overall charge, we can calculate the oxidation state of carbon.</p>\r\n<p>Let's assume the oxidation state of carbon as x. We have four oxygen atoms, each with an oxidation state of -2. The reactant that produces the least amount of CO<sub>2</sub> based on the stoichiometry will limit the amount of CO<sub>2</sub> produced.</p>\r\n<p>From the balanced equation: 2 C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub> + 7 O<sub>2</sub> ➞ 4 CO<sub>2</sub> + 6 H<sub>2</sub>O</p>\r\n<p>Moles of C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub> = ${a} moles <br>Moles of O<sub>2</sub> = ${b} moles</p>\r\n<p>To determine the limiting reactant, we compare the the amounts of product we can produce from each reactant.</p>\r\n<p>The stoichiometric ratio between C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub> and CO<sub>2</sub> is 2:4. This means that 2 moles of C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub>&nbsp;react to produce 4 moles of CO<sub>2</sub>.</p>\r\n<p>The theoretical yield of CO<sub>2</sub> based on the C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub> being the limiting reagent: Moles of limiting reactant (C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub>) × Stoichiometric coefficient of CO<sub>2</sub> = ${a} moles × (4 mol CO<sub>2</sub> / 2 mol C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub>) = =[${a}*4/2] moles CO<sub>2<br></sub><br>The stoichiometric ratio between O<sub>2</sub> and CO<sub>2</sub> is 7:4. This means that 7 moles of O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;react to produce 4 moles of CO<sub>2</sub>.</p>\r\n<p>The theoretical yield of CO<sub>2</sub> based on the O<sub>2</sub> being the limiting reagent: Moles of limiting reactant (O<sub>2</sub>) × Stoichiometric coefficient of CO<sub>2</sub> = ${b} moles × (4 mol CO<sub>2</sub> / 7 mol O<sub>2</sub>) = =[${b}*4/7] moles CO<sub>2</sub></p>\r\n<p>Since assuming O<sub>2</sub> is the limiting reagent produces a lower yield, O<sub>2</sub> is actually our limiting reactant.&nbsp;&nbsp;<br><br>Therefore, the theoretical yield of CO<sub>2</sub> from the given reaction is approximately =[${b}*4/7] moles CO<sub>2</sub>.</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"What is the limiting reactant when ${a 10 14 3} moles of ZnS react with ${b 10.0 18 3} moles of AlP?\r\n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">3 ZnS + 2 AlP ➞ Zn<sub>3</sub>P<sub>2</sub> + Al<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub></div>","choices":["ZnS","AlP","Zn<sub>3</sub>P<sub>2</sub>","Al<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>To determine the limiting reactant, we need to compare the moles of each product we could produce from the moles of each reactant, assuming the other reactant is in excess.&nbsp; The reactant that produces fewer moles of product will be the limiting reactant.</p>\r\n<p>From the balanced equation: 3 ZnS + 2 AlP ➞ Zn<sub>3</sub>P<sub>2</sub> + Al<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub></p>\r\n<p>The stoichiometric ratio between ZnS and AlP is 3:2. This means that 3 moles of ZnS react with 2 moles of AlP.</p>\r\n<p>Moles of ZnS = ${a} moles <br>Moles of AlP = ${b} moles</p>\r\n<p>To determine the limiting reactant, we compare the moles of reactant (assuming ZnS is in excess):<br>Moles of AlP x (1 mol Zn<sub>3</sub>P<sub>2</sub> / 2 mol ZnS)&nbsp; = ${b} moles x (1 / 2) = =[${b}/2] Moles of reactant when ${a 5 10 3} g of B<sub>2</sub>Br<sub>6</sub> react with ${b 15 20 3} g of HNO<sub>3</sub>?\r\n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">B<sub>2</sub>Br<sub>6</sub> + 6 HNO<sub>3</sub> ➞ 2 B(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> + 6 HBr</div>","choices":["HNO<sub>3</sub>","B<sub>2</sub>Br<sub>6</sub>","B(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>","HBr"],"correct":["1"],"solution":"<p>To determine the limiting reactant, we need to compare the amount of product that can be formed from each reactant.</p>\r\n<p>First, let's calculate the moles of each reactant: Molar mass of B<sub>2</sub>Br<sub>6</sub> = 2 * (10.81 g/mol of B) + 6 * (79.90 g/mol of Br) = 370.48 g/mol <br>Moles of B<sub>2</sub>Br<sub>6</sub> = ${a} g / 370.48 g/mol = =[${a}/370.48] mol</p>\r\n<p>Molar mass of HNO<sub>3</sub> = 1 * (1.01 g/mol of H) + 1 * (14.01 g/mol of N) + 3 * (16.00 g/mol of O) = 63.02 g/mol <br>Moles of HNO<sub>3</sub> = ${b} g / 63.02 g/mol = =[${b}/63.02] mol</p>\r\n<p>Next, we need to compare the mole ratios between B<sub>2</sub>Br<sub>6</sub> and HNO<sub>3</sub> in the balanced equation: From the equation, we see that the mole ratio between B(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and B<sub>2</sub>Br<sub>6</sub> and is 2:1. <br>The mole ratio between B(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and HNO<sub>3</sub> is 2:6.</p>\r\n<p>So, using the mole ratios, we can determine the amount of B(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> that can be formed: <br><br>Moles of B(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> formed assuming B<sub>2</sub>Br<sub>6</sub> is the limiting reactant = =[${a}/370.48] mol B<sub>2</sub>Br<sub>6</sub> * (2 mol B(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> / 1 mol B<sub>2</sub>Br<sub>6</sub>) = 0.0532 mol B(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub></p>\r\n<p>Moles of B(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> formed assuming HNO<sub>3</sub> is the limiting reactant = =[${b}/63.02] mol HNO<sub>3</sub> * (2 mol B(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> / 6 mol HNO<sub>3</sub>) = 0.0847 mol B(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub></p>\r\n<p>Based on the mole ratios, we can see that B<sub>2</sub>Br<sub>6</sub> is the limiting reactant because it forms less moles of B(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> compared to the moles formed by HNO<sub>3</sub>.</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"What is the theoretical yield, in grams of CO<sub>2</sub>, from the reaction of ${a 2 5.9 3} moles of C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub> with ${b 30 40 3} moles of O<sub>2</sub>?\r\n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub> + 5 O<sub>2</sub> ➞ 3 CO<sub>2</sub> + 4 H<sub>2</sub>O</div>","choices":["=[${a}*3*44.01] g","=[${a}*3] g","=[${b}/5*3*44.01] g","=[${a}/3*44.01] g"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<p>To determine the theoretical yield of CO<sub>2</sub> in grams, we need to calculate the stoichiometric ratio between C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>2</sub> and CO<sub>2</sub> in the balanced chemical equation. The stoichiometric ratio is the ratio of moles of reactants and products involved in the reaction.</p>\r\n<p>From the balanced equation: 1 mole of C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub> reacts to produce 3 moles of CO<sub>2</sub>.</p>\r\n<p>Given: <br>Number of moles of C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub> = ${a} mol<br>Number of moles of O2 = ${b} mol</p>\r\n<p>We will use the stoichiometry to determine the maximum number of grams of CO<sub>2</sub> we could produce assuming each reactant was the limiting reactant:</p>\r\n<p>Assuming C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub> is the limiting reactant:<br>Number of grams of CO<sub>2</sub> = (${a} mol C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub>) × (3 mol CO<sub>2</sub> / 1 mol C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub>) x (44.01 g CO<sub>2</sub> / 1 mol CO<sub>2</sub>) = =[${a}*3*44.01] g CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;<br><br>Assuming O<sub>2</sub> is the limiting reactant:<br>Number of grams of CO<sub>2</sub> = (${b} mol O<sub>2</sub>) × (3 mol CO<sub>2</sub> / 5 mol C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub>) x (44.01 g CO<sub>2</sub> / 1 mol CO<sub>2</sub>) = =[${b}*3/5*44.01] g CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;<br><br>Since C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub> produces fewer grams of our reactant, the theoretical yield is =[${a}*3*44.01] g CO<sub>2</sub></p>"},{"group":"","stem":"<span style=\"font-size: 10.5pt;\">What is the percent yield of the reaction if ${b 18.4 19.5 3} g of Fe are produced when ${a 10.0 15 3}g of Al&nbsp; Therefore, for every 1 mole of Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, we expect to produce 2 moles of Fe.</p>\r\n<p>Molar mass of Fe = 55.85 g/mol <br>Molar mass of Al = 26.98 g/mol</p>\r\n<p>Theoretical yield covalent bond is formed when two atoms share electrons in order to achieve a stable electron configuration. In a covalent bond, the atoms involved have similar electronegativity, meaning they have similar tendencies to attract electrons. This sharing of electrons allows both atoms to fill their outermost energy levels and achieve greater stability.<br><br>An ionic bond is formed when electrons are transferred from one atom to another, resulting in the formation of ions. In an ionic bond, one atom donates electrons to another atom, resulting in the formation of a positively charged ion (cation) and a negatively charged ion (anion). The attraction between these opposite charges holds the ions together and forms an ionic bond."},{"group":"laws","stem":"The statement \"if two elements form more than one compound the ratios of the position in the periodic table and their tendency to gain or lose electrons to achieve a stable electron configuration.</p>\r\n<p>Sodium (Na) tends to lose one electron to achieve a stable electron configuration, forming a +1 ion (Na<sup>+</sup>). Magnesium (Mg) tends to lose two electrons, forming a +2 ion (Mg<sup>2+</sup>). Aluminum (Al) also tends to lose three electrons, forming a +3 ion (A<sup>l3+</sup>). Nitrogen (N) tends to gain three electrons to achieve a stable electron configuration, forming a -3 ion (N<sup>3-</sup>). Oxygen (O) tends to gain two electrons, forming a -2 ion (O<sup>2-</sup>). Fluorine (F) tends to gain one electron, forming a -1 ion (F<sup>-</sup>).</p>\r\n<p>So, the predicted charges for these elements as ions are: Sodium: +1 Magnesium: +2 Aluminum: +3 Nitrogen: -3 Oxygen: -2 Fluorine: -1</p>"},{"group":"","stem":"When a neutral atom ${loses, gains} an electron it becomes a(n) ____________, with a _____________ charge.","choices":["${cation, anion}, ${positive, negative}","${anion, cation}, ${positive, negative}","${cation, anion}, ${negative, positive}","${anion, cation}, ${negative, positive}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"When a neutral atom ${loses, gains} an electron, it becomes a ${positively, negatively} charged ion called a ${cation, anion}. &nbsp;${Cation, Anion} have a net ${positive, negative} charge. states that ${no two electrons can have the same four quantum numbers, when filling degenerate orbitals they must fill with electrons with parallel spins before an electron with an opposing spin, at ground state electrons will fill the lowest energy orbitals first, it is not possible to know the exact position and velocity of an electron at the same time}?","choices":["${Pauli exclusion principle, Hund's rule, Aufbau principle, Heisenberg uncertainty principle}","${Hund's rule, Aufbau principle, Heisenberg uncertainty principle, Pauli exclusion principle}","${Aufbau principle, Heisenberg uncertainty principle, Pauli exclusion principle, Hund's rule}","${Heisenberg uncertainty principle, Pauli exclusion principle, Hund's rule, Aufbau principle}"],"correct":["0"],"solution":"<ol>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Pauli Exclusion Principle: This principle states that no two electrons in an atom can have the same set of four quantum numbers (n, l, ml, ms). In other words, each electron in an atom must have a unique combination of quantum numbers.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Hund's Rule: According to Hund's Rule, when filling degenerate orbitals (orbitals with the same energy), electrons will occupy separate orbitals with parallel spins before pairing up with opposite spins. This rule ensures that electrons maximize their overall stability.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Aufbau Principle: The Aufbau Principle states that electrons fill the lowest energy orbitals available before moving to higher energy orbitals. Electrons will occupy orbitals in order of increasing energy, following the order of the periodic table.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n<li>\r\n<p>Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle: The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle states that it is not possible to simultaneously determine the exact position and momentum (or velocity) of an electron with absolute precision. There is an inherent uncertainty in measuring these two properties, and the more precisely one property is known, the less precisely the other can be determined.</p>\r\n</li>\r\n</ol>"},{"group":"","stem":"Which of the following represents ${a ground state nitrogen atom, a violation of the Pauli exclusion principle, a violation of Hund's rule, a
